Wagner was a leading member of the Vienna Secession movement of architecture , founded in 1897 , and the broader Art Nouveau movement
Wagner born  in 1841 in Penzing , a district in Vienna
Wagner studied  in 1860 under Carl Ferdinand Busse , a classicist and student of Karl Friedrich Schinkel , the leader of the German school of neoclassical and neo - Gothic architecture
Wagner described his own style as " a sort of free Renaissance " During this period , which lasted until about 1880
Wagner wrote only that which is practical can be beautiful In 1896 in his book Modern Architecture
Wagner began to construct buildings of which he was both the architect and investor in the project , sharing in the financial benefits In the 1880s
Wagner designed a luxury apartment building on Stadiongasse in Vienna , close to the Parliament and the city hall In 1882
Wagner won the design competition in 1882
Wagner became increasingly interested in urban planning In the 1890s
Wagner named artistic counselor for the new Stadtbahn In April 1894
Wagner became Professor of Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts Vienna In 1894

Wagner expressed the necessity of leaving behind historical forms and romanticism and developing Architectural Realism , where the form was determined by the function of the building In 1894 increasingly
Wagner published a textbook entitled Modern Architecture in which he expressed his ideas about the role of the architect In 1896
Wagner aligned himself with Vienna Secession , a movement started by fifty Vienna artists formally known as the Association of Austrian plastic artists In 1897
Wagner had the bathroom displayed at the 1900 Paris Universal Exposition
Wagner achieved an international reputation By 1905 , the year he left the Vienna Secession

Wagner published a series of books on topics including theater architecture , hotel architecture , and a particularly forward - looking work , " The Great City " , published in 1911 , devoted to urban planning , explaining how the expansion of large cities should be managed
Wagner traveled to New York in 1910
Wagner participated in the International Congress of Architecture in London in 1906
Wagner named Vice President of the Permanent Commission of Congress of Fine Arts in Paris in 1912
Wagner proposed a very modern municipal museum for Vienna dedicated to The Emperor Franz - Joseph In 1912
Wagner became an honorary professor at the Academy In 1913
Wagner sold the house in September 1916

biographies.text: Otto Koloman Wagner (German: [ˈɔto ˈkoːloman ˈvaːɡnɐ] (listen); 13 July 1841 – 11 April 1918) was an Austrian architect, furniture designer and urban planner. He was a leading member of the Vienna Secession movement of architecture, founded in 1897, and the broader Art Nouveau movement. Many of his works are found in his native city of Vienna, and illustrate the rapid evolution of architecture during the period. His early works were inspired by classical architecture.  By mid-1890s, he had already designed several buildings in what became known as the Vienna Secession style.  Beginning in 1898, with his designs of Vienna Metro stations, his style became floral and Art Nouveau,  with decoration by Koloman Moser. His later works, 1906 until his death in 1918,  had geometric forms and minimal ornament, clearly expressing their function. They are considered predecessors to   modern architecture.
